sections.text: A diary entry is like talking to yourself in a notebook. You write about what happened to you, what you saw, and how you felt. It is your secret book where you can be honest about everything. It helps you remember things later and is a good friend to share your feelings with. [1]

examples.label: Purpose
examples.value: To record daily events and feelings.

examples.label: Privacy
examples.value: It is usually private, for your eyes only.

examples.label: Friend
examples.value: Think of your diary as a good friend you can tell anything to.

examples.label: Memory
examples.value: It helps you remember things later.

examples.label: Feelings
examples.value: You can write about happy, sad, or angry feelings.

examples.label: Honesty
examples.value: Be honest about your thoughts and feelings. [5]

examples.label: Reflection
examples.value: It helps you reflect on your day and actions. [2]

examples.label: Skill
examples.value: Learning diary writing is an important writing skill. [4]

examples.label: Daily Record
examples.value: It is a personal daily record of events and observations. [7]

examples.label: Self-Expression
examples.value: It is a way to express yourself freely. [12]

usage_examples: I wrote about my day in my diary.
My diary has all my secret thoughts.
Writing in my diary helps me think clearly.
I read my old diary to remember my childhood.
She writes about her village life every night.
I will write about my feelings in my diary.
My diary is my personal space.
I use my diary to remember important moments.

I always keep my diary near my bed.

subtopics.title: Key Parts of a Diary Entry

sections.text: Every diary entry usually starts with the date, day, and sometimes the time. [1, 4, 7] Then, you write about your experiences, thoughts, and feelings. You can start with 'Dear Diary' and end with your name or a simple closing. [1, 4, 7]

examples.label: Date and Day
examples.value: Always write the full date and the day (e.g., 18th July 2025, Friday). [1, 4, 5]

examples.label: Time (Optional)
examples.value: You can also add the time you are writing (e.g., 9:00 PM). [4, 7]

examples.label: Salutation (Optional)
examples.value: Like 'Dear Diary,' or just start directly. [1, 5, 7]

examples.label: Body
examples.value: This is where you describe events, thoughts, and feelings in paragraphs. [1, 4, 7]

examples.label: Closing (Optional)
examples.value: Like 'Good night,' or 'Until tomorrow,' or 'Bye dear diary'. [1, 7]

examples.label: Signature (Optional)
examples.value: Your name or initials at the end. [1, 4, 7]

examples.label: First Person
examples.value: Always write using 'I' statements, as it's your personal record. [5, 6, 12]

examples.label: Chronological Order
examples.value: Tell events in the order they happened during the day. [6, 12]

examples.label: Focus
examples.value: Focus on personal feelings, thoughts, and opinions. [1]

examples.label: Language
examples.value: Use informal and friendly language. [4, 7, 12]

usage_examples: I started my entry with 'Today, 18th July 2025, Friday'.
After the date, I wrote about my visit to the market.
I ended my diary entry by just signing my name.
Dear Diary, today was a busy day.
I wrote the date clearly on top of the page.
I always start with the day and date.
I write what happened to me first.
Then I write how I felt about it.
I sometimes write 'Good night' at the end.
My diary is my secret friend.

table.title: Typical Diary Entry Structure
rows: Always write the full date and the day (e.g., July 18, 2025, Friday). [1, 4]
Write the time you are writing the entry (e.g., 9:00 PM). [4, 7]
Like 'Dear Diary,' or just start directly. [1, 5]
Describe events, thoughts, and feelings in paragraphs. Write in chronological order. [1, 6, 12]

sections.text: This is the main part of your diary. Write about what you did, what you saw, and who you met. Be specific and include details. Imagine you are telling a friend about your day. [5, 12]

sections.text: Your diary is a safe place to share your thoughts and feelings. [1, 5] Don't just write what happened, but also how you felt about it. Were you happy, sad, angry, surprised, worried, or excited? [1, 2, 3, 5]

topics.title: Using Past Tense in Diary Entries

sections.text: When you write in a diary, you are usually writing about things that already happened. So, you will use past tense verbs a lot. [6, 7, 8, 9, 12] The simple past tense describes actions completed in the past.

table.title: Common Verbs in Simple Past Tense

sections.text: The past continuous tense is used for actions that were ongoing at a specific time in the past. It uses 'was' or 'were' + verb-ing. It tells what you were doing when something else happened.

examples.value: I was reading a book when my friend called.

topics.title: Enriching Your Diary with Emotional Vocabulary

sections.text: To express your happiness clearly, use different words. Instead of just 'happy', you can use words like 'joyful', 'excited', 'glad', 'delighted', 'pleased'. [14, 15, 16] Using more specific words helps you communicate better. [15]

subtopics.title: Sample Entry 1: A Day at School

sections.text: Here is an example of a simple diary entry about a day at school. Remember to use simple language and short sentences, just like you would speak. [1, 24]
usage_examples:
July 17, 2025, Thursday
Dear Diary,
Today was a good day at school. We had a new English lesson. Our teacher taught us about different kinds of sentences. I understood it well. After school, I played kho-kho with my friends. I was happy because our team won. Then I went home and helped my mother. I felt tired but also good about the day.
Good night,
[Your Name]

subtopics.title: Sample Entry 2: Helping on the Farm

sections.text: Here is an example of a diary entry about helping on the farm. Notice how it describes actions and feelings. [1, 5, 6, 12]
usage_examples:
July 16, 2025, Wednesday
Dear Diary,
This morning, I woke up early and went to the farm with my father. We worked in the paddy fields. The sun was very hot, and I felt tired. But it was important work. We planted many saplings. In the evening, my father praised my hard work. I felt proud and happy. I hope the harvest will be good this year.
[Your Name]

subtopics.title: Practice Activity: Write Your Own Diary Entry

sections.text:
Now it's your turn. Write a diary entry about your day. Remember to include: [2, 5]
1.  Date and Day
2.  What happened (personal experiences)
3.  How you felt (thoughts and feelings)
4.  Use past tense verbs for events. [6, 7, 8, 9]

Try to write at least 5-7 sentences. You can write about: [2, 5]
*   What you did today at school or home.
*   Something interesting you saw.
*   How you helped someone.
*   A game you played.
*   Any special event in your village.
usage_examples: Think about your morning: What did you eat? What did you see?
Think about your afternoon: Did you go to school? Did you study?
Think about your evening: Did you play? Did you help at home?
How did you feel about these things?
What was the most important thing that happened?
Did you learn something new today?
Did anything surprise you?
What are you looking forward to tomorrow?
Did you face any challenges, and how did you feel about them?
Who did you meet today, and how was your interaction?
